none.$description: No border (0px). Use for: removing inherited borders, borderless variants, flat designs. CSS: border-width: 0; Common in: ghost buttons, flat cards, seamless containers.

thin.$description: Thin border (1px). DEFAULT for most UI borders. Use for: input fields, cards, tables, subtle containment, dividers. Provides structure without visual weight. Common in: Input, Select, Card, Table, dividers, most bordered elements.

medium.$description: Medium border (2px). Use for: emphasis, active/selected states, focus indicators, section dividers. More prominent than thin - draws attention. Common in: active tab indicators, selected items, heavy dividers, emphasized cards.

thick.$description: Thick border (4px). Use for: strong emphasis, decorative elements, major section dividers, brand accents. Very prominent - use sparingly. Common in: hero sections, brand elements, major visual accents, side indicators.

solid.$description: Solid border style. DEFAULT for all standard borders. Use for: inputs, cards, buttons, tables, containers. Continuous line - clean and professional. CSS keyword.

dashed.$description: Dashed border style. Use for: drop zones, placeholder elements, 'add new' areas, temporary states, grouping without containment. Suggests incompleteness or potential. Common in: drag-and-drop zones, placeholder cards, dashed separators.

dotted.$description: Dotted border style. Use for: decorative elements, subtle separators, accessibility focus alternatives, lightweight boundaries. Softer than dashed. Common in: decorative dividers, coupon borders, alternative focus styles.

none.$description: No border style. Use for: removing inherited borders, clean/minimal designs, when using other separation methods. CSS keyword. Equivalent to border-style: none;.

white.$description: Pure white. Use for: light theme backgrounds, text on dark backgrounds, card surfaces. Contrast ratio with black: 21:1 (WCAG AAA). Avoid using directly - prefer semantic tokens like color.body or color.default.

black.$description: Pure black. Use for: dark theme text emphasis, high-contrast borders. Contrast ratio with white: 21:1 (WCAG AAA). Rarely used directly - prefer dark.9 for softer blacks or semantic color.text token.

transparent.$description: Fully transparent. Use for: invisible interactive areas, overlay starting states, clearfix backgrounds. CSS keyword value - works in all color contexts.

0.$description: Lightest dark - text color on dark backgrounds, disabled states on dark theme

1.$description: Light dark - secondary text on dark theme, subtle borders

2.$description: Mid-light dark - placeholder text on dark theme, icons

3.$description: Medium dark - dimmed text, decorative elements

4.$description: Mid dark - borders on dark theme, dividers

5.$description: Base dark - elevated surfaces on dark theme, cards

6.$description: Dark base - primary dark theme background, app shells

7.$description: Darker - alternative dark background, sidebar backgrounds

8.$description: Very dark - modal overlays on dark theme, deep shadows

9.$description: Darkest - near-black for maximum contrast elements

0.$description: Lightest gray - subtle backgrounds, hover states on white, zebra striping

1.$description: Light gray - input backgrounds, disabled backgrounds, table headers

2.$description: Mid-light gray - borders, dividers, inactive tabs

3.$description: Medium gray - placeholder text (use carefully - check contrast), icons

4.$description: Mid gray - secondary icons, chart gridlines

5.$description: Base gray - dimmed text, help text (4.5:1 on white = AA)

6.$description: Dark gray - secondary text (7:1 on white = AAA), labels

7.$description: Darker gray - primary text alternative, emphasis

8.$description: Very dark gray - high-emphasis text on light backgrounds

9.$description: Darkest gray - headings, maximum emphasis text

0.$description: Lightest red - error alert backgrounds, validation field backgrounds

1.$description: Light red - hover state for error backgrounds

3.$description: Medium red - icons on error backgrounds

4.$description: Mid red - error icons on white backgrounds

5.$description: Base red - primary destructive buttons, critical alerts

6.$description: Dark red - error text on white (6:1 contrast = AA), danger buttons

7.$description: Darker red - error text with maximum contrast (8:1 = AAA)

8.$description: Very dark red - text on light red backgrounds

9.$description: Darkest red - reserved for extreme emphasis

0.$description: Lightest pink - subtle highlights, badge backgrounds

1.$description: Light pink - hover states, selected rows

6.$description: Dark pink - text on light pink backgrounds (AA compliant)

8.$description: Very dark pink - text on light backgrounds

6.$description: Dark grape - text on light grape backgrounds
Dark violet - text on light backgrounds
Dark indigo - text on light backgrounds

0.$description: Lightest blue - primary light backgrounds, selected row highlights

1.$description: Light blue - hover backgrounds, info alert backgrounds

3.$description: Medium blue - icons on light backgrounds

4.$description: Mid blue - primary buttons on dark theme, links on dark

5.$description: Base blue - primary buttons, links (light theme)

6.$description: Dark blue - primary brand color, main CTAs, navigation active states

7.$description: Darker blue - pressed states, text on light blue backgrounds

8.$description: Very dark blue - high contrast text

9.$description: Darkest blue - maximum emphasis, dark accents

6.$description: Dark cyan - text on light backgrounds
Dark teal - text on light backgrounds

0.$description: Lightest green - success alert backgrounds, positive feedback areas

1.$description: Light green - hover state for success backgrounds

2.$description: Mid-light green - progress indicators, completion bars

3.$description: Medium green - success icons on light backgrounds

4.$description: Mid green - success badges, online indicators

5.$description: Base green - primary success buttons, checkmarks

6.$description: Dark green - success text on white (5:1 contrast = AA)

7.$description: Darker green - success text with maximum contrast

8.$description: Very dark green - text on light green backgrounds

6.$description: Dark lime - text on light backgrounds

1.$description: Light yellow - hover state for warning backgrounds

2.$description: Mid-light yellow - caution icons with dark stroke

3.$description: Medium yellow - warning badges (ensure dark text)

5.$description: Base yellow - rarely used for text

xs.$description: Extra small breakpoint (576px). Use for: large phones in landscape, small tablets. Content starts having room to breathe. Typical changes: side-by-side layouts begin, hiding mobile-only elements. Above this: no longer 'mobile-only' context.

sm.$description: Small breakpoint (768px). Use for: tablets in portrait, small laptops. Two-column layouts become comfortable. Typical changes: sidebars can appear, cards go 2-up, navigation expands. Common tablet breakpoint. Desktop-like experiences begin here.

md.$description: Medium breakpoint (992px). Use for: tablets in landscape, standard laptops, small desktops. Full desktop layouts are comfortable. Typical changes: three-column layouts, full navigation, expanded sidebars. Most 'desktop' designs target this minimum.

lg.$description: Large breakpoint (1200px). Use for: large laptops, standard desktop monitors. Generous space available. Typical changes: four-column grids, expanded dashboards, side panels. Content max-widths often kick in here to prevent over-stretching.

xl.$description: Extra large breakpoint (1408px). Use for: large desktop monitors, high-resolution displays. Maximum layouts. Typical changes: ultra-wide layouts, multi-panel views, data-dense dashboards. Consider max-width constraints - too wide hurts readability.

sm.$description: Small content width (600px). Use for: prose content, documentation, blog posts, reading-focused layouts. Optimal line length for readability (~65-75 characters). Common in: article bodies, help documentation, settings panels, narrow modals.

lg.$description: Large content width (1280px). Use for: full application layouts, dashboards, data-heavy interfaces. Maximum comfortable width for most content. Common in: main app container, dashboard layouts, admin interfaces. Beyond this, consider multi-column or sidebar layouts.

xs.$description: Extra small radius (2px). Use for: small badges, tags, inline code blocks, tiny indicators, nested elements inside sm-radius containers. Barely perceptible rounding - softens without calling attention. Common in: chip components, status dots, code snippets.

sm.$description: Small radius (4px). DEFAULT for small components. Use for: buttons, inputs, dropdowns, tooltips, small cards, table cells. The workhorse radius - professional and subtle. Most form elements use this. Common in: Button, Input, Select, Badge, Alert.

md.$description: Medium radius (8px). Use for: cards, modals, dialogs, larger containers, image thumbnails, panels. Creates friendly, approachable feel without being playful. Common in: Card, Modal, Popover, larger interactive surfaces.

lg.$description: Large radius (16px). Use for: hero cards, featured content, marketing components, prominent UI elements. Noticeably rounded - use intentionally for emphasis or friendly tone. Common in: feature cards, promotional banners, onboarding modals.

xl.$description: Extra large radius (32px). Use for: hero sections, large promotional elements, artistic layouts, very large cards. Significantly rounded - creates soft, approachable aesthetic. Use sparingly - can feel too casual for business applications.

full.$description: Full/pill radius (circular). Use for: avatar circles, round buttons, pill-shaped tags, circular indicators, FABs. Creates perfect circles on square elements or pill shapes on rectangles. Common in: Avatar, round IconButton, pill Badge, circular progress.

xs.$description: Extra small input height (30px). Use for: compact forms, inline editing, space-constrained UIs.

sm.$description: Small input height (36px). Use for: secondary inputs, compact layouts, mobile-optimized forms.

md.$description: Medium input height (42px). DEFAULT size for most inputs. Use for: standard forms, primary data entry.

lg.$description: Large input height (48px). Use for: prominent inputs, touch-optimized UIs, hero forms.

xl.$description: Extra large input height (60px). Use for: marketing forms, high-emphasis inputs, accessibility focus.

xs.$description: Extra small button height (30px). Use for: inline actions, compact toolbars, icon-only buttons.

sm.$description: Small button height (36px). Use for: secondary actions, compact layouts, less prominent CTAs.

md.$description: Medium button height (42px). DEFAULT size for most buttons. Use for: primary actions, form submits.

lg.$description: Large button height (48px). Use for: prominent CTAs, hero sections, touch-optimized UIs.

xl.$description: Extra large button height (60px). Use for: marketing CTAs, high-emphasis actions.

xs.$description: Extra small icon size (12px). Use for: inline indicators, badge icons, compact UIs.

sm.$description: Small icon size (16px). Use for: inline icons, button icons with text, input icons.

md.$description: Medium icon size (20px). DEFAULT for most icons. Use for: standalone icons, navigation icons.

lg.$description: Large icon size (24px). Use for: prominent icons, action icons, toolbar icons.

xl.$description: Extra large icon size (32px). Use for: feature icons, empty state illustrations, marketing icons.

2.$description: Micro spacing (2px). Use for: hairline gaps, subtle visual separations, icon optical adjustments, fine-tuning alignment. Common in: stacked icons, tight inline elements, border spacing, minimal breathing room between dense elements.

4.$description: Very small spacing (4px). Use for: compact component internal gaps, tight list items, dense table cell padding, icon-to-text micro gaps. Common in: tags, badges, compact chips, dense data displays, inline code blocks.

8.$description: Small spacing (8px). Use for: tight padding in compact components, icon-to-text gaps, small button padding, dense form layouts. Common in: small buttons, compact inputs, toolbar items, pill badges, tight card grids.

12.$description: Standard small spacing (12px). Use for: standard component internal padding, form field padding, list item padding, comfortable compact UIs. Common in: buttons, inputs, dropdowns, list items, alert padding, menu items.

16.$description: Base spacing (16px). DEFAULT spacing value. Use for: standard gaps between elements, default component padding, card content padding, form group spacing. Most common spacing value in the system - the baseline reference.

20.$description: Medium spacing (20px). Use for: generous component padding, separation between related groups, comfortable breathing room. Common in: card padding, dialog content padding, section sub-dividers, relaxed form layouts.

24.$description: Large spacing (24px). Use for: modal/dialog padding, card spacing, comfortable content separation, generous component margins. Common in: modal containers, feature cards, dashboard panels, content sections.

32.$description: Extra large spacing (32px). Use for: major content block separation, large card padding, section dividers within pages. Common in: page sections, hero content padding, feature showcases, spacious card layouts.

40.$description: Section spacing (40px). Use for: significant section separation, generous layout margins, prominent content blocks. Common in: landing page sections, dashboard section gaps, major content dividers.

48.$description: Large section spacing (48px). Use for: large section breaks, page-level content separation, hero component internal spacing. Common in: page headers, major layout divisions, feature section padding.

56.$description: Page section spacing (56px). Use for: substantial page section margins, generous hero padding, prominent content area separation. Common in: landing page hero sections, major page divisions, marketing layouts.

64.$description: Major section spacing (64px). Use for: major page section breaks, hero section padding, significant layout whitespace. Common in: page-level section gaps, hero components, full-width content dividers.

72.$description: Expansive spacing (72px). Use for: very large section separation, expansive layout margins, premium whitespace. Common in: marketing pages, landing hero sections, high-emphasis content areas.

80.$description: Maximum spacing (80px). Largest spacing value. Use for: maximum section breaks, largest page margins, expansive hero sections. Common in: landing page hero areas, major page divisions, spacious marketing layouts. Use sparingly - represents maximum breathing room.

xs.$description: Extra small grid gap (8px). Use for: compact card grids, dense dashboard layouts, mobile-optimized grids, icon grids. Minimum comfortable gap for touch targets.

sm.$description: Small grid gap (16px). Use for: standard card grids, form layouts, compact dashboard grids. Good default for most grid layouts.

md.$description: Medium grid gap (24px). Use for: default content grids, spacious card layouts, comfortable dashboard grids. Balances density with readability.

lg.$description: Large grid gap (32px). Use for: spacious card layouts, content grids, marketing pages. Good for layouts with larger cards or content blocks.

xl.$description: Extra large grid gap (40px). Use for: hero grids, feature showcases, landing page layouts. Creates clear separation between grid items.

xxl.$description: Double extra large grid gap (48px). Use for: maximum separation in grids, presentation layouts, sparse artistic layouts. Rarely needed - consider if layout needs restructuring.

xs.$description: Quarter baseline (6.4px). Use for: list item spacing within tight lists, line spacing adjustments, micro-spacing in prose. Minimal vertical separation.

sm.$description: Half baseline (12.8px). Use for: heading bottom margins, spacing after inline elements, paragraph-adjacent element spacing. Creates subtle but noticeable separation.

md.$description: Single baseline (25.6px). DEFAULT prose spacing. Use for: paragraph margins, standard content block spacing, default vertical rhythm. One full line height of separation.

lg.$description: 1.5 baselines (38.4px). Use for: heading top margins, spacing before new sections within content, emphasis breaks. Creates clear topic transitions.

xl.$description: Double baseline (51.2px). Use for: major section breaks in prose, chapter-level separations, significant content divisions. Two full line heights of separation.

2xl.$description: Triple baseline (76.8px). Use for: page section breaks, major content area separations, hero-to-content transitions. Maximum prose spacing - use sparingly.

xs.$description: Extra small shadow - minimal elevation (1-2dp). Use for: subtle depth on cards at rest, input fields, low-emphasis containers, elements that could be flat. Barely noticeable - adds dimension without prominence. Common in: Card default state, Input fields, Table rows, subtle separation.

sm.$description: Small shadow - low elevation (4-6dp). Use for: card hover states, raised buttons, navigation elements, slightly prominent containers. Noticeable but not dramatic elevation. Common in: Card:hover, Button:raised, Dropdown trigger, Navigation bar, elevated sections.

md.$description: Medium shadow - moderate elevation (8-12dp). DEFAULT for floating elements. Use for: dropdown menus, popovers, tooltips, floating action buttons, autocomplete lists. Clearly floating above content. Common in: Dropdown menu, Popover, Select options, Autocomplete, FAB.

lg.$description: Large shadow - high elevation (16-24dp). Use for: dialogs, modals, drawers, notification toasts, temporary UI surfaces. Significantly elevated - demands attention. Common in: Modal dialogs, side Drawer, Toast notifications, contextual menus requiring focus.

xl.$description: Extra large shadow - maximum elevation (24dp+). Use for: critical modals, full-screen overlays, maximum prominence elements. Dramatic elevation - use sparingly. Common in: Full-screen modals, critical dialogs, onboarding overlays, image lightboxes.

inset.$description: Inset shadow - pressed/recessed appearance. Use for: pressed button states, input:focus, toggle switches (off state), embedded content areas. Creates illusion of pressing INTO the surface. Common in: Button:active, pressed toggles, embedded wells, search input backgrounds.

footer.$description: Footer shadow - upward-casting shadow for fixed footers. Use for: sticky footers, bottom navigation bars, action bars at bottom of screen. Shadow casts upward to show footer is above scrolling content. Common in: sticky page footers, bottom action bars, mobile bottom nav.

none.$description: No shadow - flat appearance. Use for: flat design elements, removing inherited shadows, elements that should appear flush with background, focus states that use outline instead. CSS keyword. Common in: flat buttons, inline elements, focus states using outline.

width.$description: Focus ring width (3px). Thick enough to be clearly visible per WCAG 2.4.11 (Focus Appearance). Use for: outline-width property. 3px provides clear visibility without being obtrusive. Consistent across all focusable elements.

offset.$description: Focus ring offset from element (2px). Creates gap between element and focus ring for clarity. Use for: outline-offset property. Prevents focus ring from overlapping element borders. Ensures ring is visible on both light and dark backgrounds.

color.$description: Focus ring color (primary blue). High-visibility color that works on most backgrounds. Reference to color.blue.5 for consistency with primary brand color. ACCESSIBILITY: Ensure 3:1 contrast ratio against adjacent colors. May need adjustment for dark theme.

base.$description: Base layer (z-index: 0). DEFAULT for all standard content. Use for: page content, cards, sections, anything in normal document flow. Establishes baseline - everything else stacks above this. Never use negative z-index unless absolutely necessary.

dropdown.$description: Dropdown layer (z-index: 100). Use for: dropdown menus, select options, autocomplete lists, combobox panels. First elevated layer - appears above base content but below sticky headers. Common in: Select menu, Dropdown, Autocomplete, Menu, Popover (when not in modal).

sticky.$description: Sticky layer (z-index: 200). Use for: sticky headers, fixed navigation, persistent UI elements, scroll-aware banners. Stays visible during scroll but below overlay content. Common in: Sticky header, fixed sidebar, persistent action bars, scroll-to-top buttons.

overlay.$description: Overlay layer (z-index: 300). Use for: modal backdrops, drawer overlays, lightbox backgrounds, focus-trap containers. Dims/blocks underlying content. Separate from modal content to allow proper stacking. Common in: Modal backdrop, Drawer backdrop, lightbox overlay.

modal.$description: Modal layer (z-index: 400). Use for: modal dialogs, side drawers, full-screen overlays, dialog content. Primary overlay content layer - above backdrop but below popovers. Common in: Modal content, Drawer content, Dialog, Sheet, full-screen menus.

popover.$description: Popover layer (z-index: 500). Use for: popovers triggered from within modals, nested floating elements, color pickers, date pickers in modals. Above modal content but below tooltips. Common in: DatePicker in modal, ColorPicker in modal, nested menus.

tooltip.$description: Tooltip layer (z-index: 600). HIGHEST standard layer. Use for: tooltips, toasts, notifications, snackbars, any element that must be visible above everything else. Always on top - critical information. Common in: Tooltip, Toast, Snackbar, notification badges, loading indicators.

instant.$description: Instant/no duration (0ms). Use for: prefers-reduced-motion fallback, immediate state changes, disabled animations, no-transition scenarios. CSS: transition-duration: 0ms; effectively disables transitions. ACCESSIBILITY: Use this as fallback for users who prefer reduced motion.

fast.$description: Fast transitions (100ms). Use for: micro-interactions, hover states, button presses, checkbox toggles, small element transitions, focus rings. Feels instantaneous but smooth. Anything faster is imperceptible. Common in: hover color changes, button active states, toggle switches, icon transitions.

normal.$description: Normal transitions (200ms). DEFAULT duration for most UI transitions. Use for: dropdown menus, tooltips, tab switches, sidebar toggles, modal fade-ins, standard UI feedback. Balanced: noticeable but not slow. Common in: Dropdown, Tooltip, Tab panels, collapsible sections.

slow.$description: Slow transitions (300ms). Use for: larger element transitions, slide-in panels, accordion expansions, page section reveals, image transitions. Gives eye time to track larger movements. Common in: sidebar slide, accordion panels, card reveals, hero image transitions.

slower.$description: Slower transitions (500ms). MAXIMUM recommended duration. Use for: full-page transitions, dramatic reveals, onboarding animations, marketing flourishes. Any longer feels unresponsive. Use sparingly - only for intentional dramatic effect. Common in: page transitions, hero animations, loading sequences.

linear.$description: Linear easing - constant speed, no acceleration. CSS: linear. Use for: progress bars, looping animations, continuous scrolling, mechanical movements. Feels robotic/artificial - avoid for UI interactions. Only use when constant speed is intentionally desired. Common in: progress indicators, loading spinners, continuous carousels.

ease.$description: Standard ease curve - CSS default. Quick start, gradual slow-down. Use for: general-purpose transitions when specific easing isn't needed. Good default but 'easeOut' often feels better for UI. CSS: ease. Common in: fallback transitions, simple state changes.

easeIn.$description: Ease in - starts slow, accelerates. CSS: ease-in. Use for: elements LEAVING the screen, dismissals, fade-outs, exits. Creates sense of departure/acceleration away. AVOID for entrances - feels sluggish. Common in: modal dismiss, toast exit, dropdown close, element removal animations.

easeOut.$description: Ease out - starts fast, decelerates. CSS: ease-out. RECOMMENDED for most UI transitions. Use for: elements ENTERING the screen, reveals, expansions, focus states. Creates sense of arrival/settling into place. Feels responsive and natural. Common in: modal open, tooltip appear, dropdown open, hover effects.

easeInOut.$description: Ease in and out - slow start, fast middle, slow end. CSS: ease-in-out. Use for: elements transforming in place, position changes, size changes, bidirectional animations. Natural for movements that start and end at rest. Common in: tab transitions, carousel slides, position animations, transform effects.

emphasized.$description: Emphasized deceleration - quick start, strong deceleration. Custom Material-inspired curve. Use for: attention-grabbing entrances, important notifications, emphasized reveals, dramatic effect. More pronounced than standard easeOut. Use sparingly for emphasis. Common in: snackbar/toast entrance, important alerts, feature reveals, celebration animations.

sans.$description: Primary sans-serif font stack. Use for: all body text, UI labels, form inputs, general content. Public Sans is a neutral, open-source typeface optimized for UI and web. Fallbacks: Helvetica Neue (macOS), Helvetica (older Mac), Arial (Windows/Linux), system sans-serif. LOADING: Include weights 400, 500, 600, 700 for full design system support.

heading.$value: 'Atkinson Hyperlegible Next', 'Atkinson Hyperlegible', 'Public Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
heading.$description: Heading/display font stack optimized for accessibility. Atkinson Hyperlegible Next (by Braille Institute) is designed for maximum legibility, especially for users with low vision. Use for: page titles, section headings, hero text, marketing content. Distinct letterforms reduce character confusion. Falls back to Public Sans for consistency.

mono.$value: ui-monospace, SFMono-Regular, Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, 'Liberation Mono', 'Courier New', monospace
mono.$description: Monospace font stack for code and technical content. Use for: code blocks, inline code, terminal output, data tables with alignment needs, API references. ui-monospace uses system default (SF Mono on Mac, Cascadia on Windows 11). Fallbacks cover all major platforms. All characters have equal width for alignment.

xs.$description: Extra small font size (12px). MINIMUM readable size. Use for: helper text, timestamps, metadata, legal text, footnotes, badge content. Requires high contrast - use with strong foreground colors. Not recommended for primary content. Common in: timestamps, version numbers, copyright notices.

sm.$description: Small font size (14px). Use for: secondary text, table content, form labels, captions, sidebar content. Comfortable for extended reading in UI contexts. Common in: data tables, form labels, navigation items, secondary buttons. Good balance of density and readability.

md.$description: Medium font size (16px). DEFAULT body text size. Use for: primary body text, paragraphs, form inputs, buttons, main content. Browser default - optimal for extended reading. WCAG baseline assumption for contrast calculations. Common in: body text, input values, primary UI text.

lg.$description: Large font size (18px). Use for: lead paragraphs, emphasized body text, large UI elements, card titles. Slightly larger for emphasis without being a heading. Common in: intro paragraphs, feature descriptions, prominent labels, large button text.

xl.$description: Extra large font size (20px). Use for: small headings (h5-h6), subtitle text, section labels, prominent UI elements. Bridges gap between body and heading sizes. Common in: card headings, modal titles, section headers within content.

2xl.$description: 2x large font size (22px). Use for: medium headings (h4), component titles, feature headings. Clearly heading-sized but not dominant. Common in: h4 headings, sidebar section titles, panel headers.

3xl.$description: 3x large font size (26px). Use for: prominent headings (h3), page section titles. Commands attention without overwhelming. Common in: h3 headings, dashboard section titles, feature section headers.

4xl.$description: 4x large font size (34px). Use for: major headings (h1-h2), page titles, hero text. Primary visual hierarchy anchor. Common in: page titles, h1/h2 headings, hero headlines. Pair with lineHeight.xs or lineHeight.sm for tighter leading.

light.$description: Light font weight (300). Use sparingly for: large display text, hero headlines, artistic/elegant contexts, stylized marketing content. CAUTION: Poor readability at small sizes or low contrast. Never use for body text or UI labels. Requires high contrast ratio. Common in: hero text, large quotes, stylized headings.

regular.$description: Regular font weight (400). DEFAULT weight for all body text. Use for: paragraphs, descriptions, general content, form input values, most UI text. Optimized for extended reading. Most content should use this weight. Common in: body text, input values, descriptions, help text.

medium.$description: Medium font weight (500). Use for: subtle emphasis, navigation items, form labels, table headers, slightly prominent UI text. Noticeable but not bold - professional emphasis. Common in: nav items, active states, form labels, table column headers, subheadings.

semibold.$description: Semibold font weight (600). Use for: buttons, important labels, card titles, moderate emphasis headings. Strong emphasis without the heaviness of bold. Common in: button text, card titles, important labels, h4-h6 headings, badge text, tab labels.

bold.$description: Bold font weight (700). Use for: headings (h1-h3), strong emphasis, critical information, maximum text prominence. Reserve for true emphasis - overuse dilutes impact. Common in: h1-h3 headings, alert titles, critical labels, strong inline emphasis (<strong>).

fontWeight.$description: Default font weight for all headings.

fontSize.$description: H1 font size (34px). Use for page titles.

fontWeight.$description: Bold weight (700) for maximum visual hierarchy on page titles.

lineHeight.$description: Tight line height for large headings.

fontSize.$description: H2 font size (26px). Use for section headings.

fontWeight.$description: Bold weight (700) for strong section hierarchy.

lineHeight.$description: Tight line height (1.2) for compact section headings.

fontSize.$description: H3 font size (22px). Use for subsection headings.

fontWeight.$description: Semibold weight (600) for clear subsection emphasis.

lineHeight.$description: Snug line height (1.35) for medium-sized headings.

fontSize.$description: H4 font size (20px). Use for card titles.

fontWeight.$description: Semibold weight (600) for card and component titles.

lineHeight.$description: Snug line height (1.35) for card title readability.

fontSize.$description: H5 font size (18px). Use for small headings.

fontWeight.$description: Semibold weight (600) for minor section emphasis.

lineHeight.$description: Snug line height (1.35) for compact minor headings.

fontSize.$description: H6 font size (16px). Use for label-like headings.

fontWeight.$description: Semibold weight (600) for label-style heading emphasis.

lineHeight.$description: Normal line height (1.5) matching body text rhythm.

tighter.$description: Tighter tracking (-0.05em). Use for: very large display text (48px+), hero headlines, logos. Brings characters closer for visual cohesion at large sizes. CAUTION: Can reduce readability if overused.

tight.$description: Slightly tight tracking (-0.025em). Use for: large headings (h1-h2), medium display text. Subtle tightening that improves visual density without sacrificing readability.

normal.$description: Default letter spacing (0). DEFAULT for all body text and most headings. Let the typeface's natural spacing work. Optimal for reading comprehension.

wide.$description: Slightly wide tracking (0.025em). Use for: small text (12px or less), captions that need more breathing room. Improves legibility at small sizes.

wider.$description: Wide tracking (0.05em). Use for: small caps, labels, overlines, all-caps text. Prevents all-caps text from feeling cramped. Common in: button text (sometimes), navigation labels, category headers.

widest.$description: Maximum tracking (0.1em). Use for: stylistic emphasis, spaced-out headings, decorative typography. Very pronounced spacing for special typographic treatments. Use sparingly.

xs.$description: Tight line height (1.2 / 120%). Use for: large display headings, hero text, single-line elements, buttons, badges. Text appears compact and impactful. CAUTION: Not accessible for multi-line body text. Only use for headings 24px+ or single-line UI elements. Common in: h1, hero headlines, button text, badge labels.

sm.$description: Snug line height (1.35 / 135%). Use for: smaller headings (h3-h6), subheadings, short multi-line text, compact interfaces. Tighter than body but readable for short passages. Common in: h3-h6 headings, card titles, navigation items, form labels, compact UI text.

md.$description: Normal line height (1.5 / 150%). WCAG MINIMUM for body text. Use for: standard body text, paragraphs, UI descriptions, form inputs, most readable content. Baseline for accessibility compliance. Common in: body paragraphs, descriptions, form values, help text, table cells.

lg.$description: Relaxed line height (1.65 / 165%). Use for: longer paragraphs, improved readability, wide content areas, users who need more visual separation. Better for sustained reading. Common in: article content, documentation, expanded descriptions, accessibility-focused interfaces.

xl.$description: Loose line height (1.8 / 180%). Use for: long-form prose, documentation, maximum readability, accessibility accommodations. Very generous spacing between lines. Common in: blog posts, help documentation, legal text, content prioritizing readability over density.

0.$description: Fully transparent (0%). Use for: hidden elements, animation start states, invisible interactive areas. Element is invisible but may still be interactive. CSS: opacity: 0; visibility: hidden for truly hidden.

5.$description: 5% opacity - barely visible. Use for: extremely subtle hover states, ghost backgrounds, near-invisible separators. Only visible against high-contrast backgrounds.

10.$description: 10% opacity - subtle transparency. Use for: light hover backgrounds, subtle shadows, faint overlays. Minimally perceptible change.

20.$description: 20% opacity - light transparency. Use for: hover states, light overlays, muted backgrounds. Noticeable but unobtrusive.

25.$description: 25% opacity - quarter visible. Use for: skeleton loading states, light dimming, subtle backgrounds. Common for placeholder content.

30.$description: 30% opacity - moderate transparency. Use for: image overlays, text shadows, moderate dimming. Visible but allows content behind to show clearly.

40.$description: 40% opacity - semi-transparent. Use for: medium overlays, watermarks, partially hidden content. Balanced visibility.

50.$description: 50% opacity - half visible. Use for: disabled elements (semantic alias: 'disabled'), balanced overlays, de-emphasized content. CAUTION: May not meet contrast requirements for text.

60.$description: 60% opacity - mostly visible. Use for: modal backdrops (semantic alias: 'overlay'), dimmed backgrounds, focus-drawing overlays. Content behind is visible but de-emphasized.

70.$description: 70% opacity - high visibility. Use for: heavy overlays, strong dimming, de-emphasized backgrounds. Most content visible but clearly secondary.

75.$description: 75% opacity - three-quarters visible. Use for: dark overlays, strong backgrounds, significant dimming. Mostly solid with hint of transparency.

80.$description: 80% opacity - mostly solid. Use for: nearly-opaque overlays, frosted glass effects (with backdrop-filter), heavy backgrounds.

90.$description: 90% opacity - nearly solid. Use for: subtle transparency effects, slight see-through, glass-like surfaces. Almost indistinguishable from solid.

100.$description: Fully opaque (100%). Use for: solid elements, removing inherited transparency, default element state. CSS: opacity: 1; (default browser value).

disabled.$description: Disabled element opacity (50%). SEMANTIC alias for opacity.50. Use for: disabled buttons, inactive controls, unavailable options. Universally recognized as 'inactive'. ACCESSIBILITY: Ensure disabled elements are still perceivable and their disabled state is communicated via aria-disabled.

overlay.$description: Modal overlay opacity (60%). SEMANTIC alias for opacity.60. Use for: modal backdrops, lightbox backgrounds, focus-drawing overlays. Dims background while keeping it visible for context. Common in: Modal backdrop, Drawer overlay, image lightbox backgrounds.
